## Description {#details}

<a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/target">Target</a> specific streamer interface.

This is used so that targets can implement support for target specific assembly directives.

If target foo wants to use this, it should implement 3 classes:
<ul>
<li>FooTargetStreamer : public <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/mctargetstreamer">MCTargetStreamer</a></li>
<li>FooTargetAsmStreamer : public FooTargetStreamer</li>
<li>FooTargetELFStreamer : public FooTargetStreamer</li>
</ul>


FooTargetStreamer should have a pure virtual method for each directive. For example, for a &quot;.bar symbol&#95;name&quot; directive, it should have virtual emitBar(const MCSymbol &amp;Symbol) = 0;

The FooTargetAsmStreamer and FooTargetELFStreamer classes implement the method. The assembly streamer just prints &quot;.bar symbol&#95;name&quot;. The object streamer does whatever is needed to implement .bar in the object file.

In the assembly printer and parser the target streamer can be used by calling getTargetStreamer and casting it to FooTargetStreamer:

<a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/mctargetstreamer">MCTargetStreamer</a> &amp;TS = OutStreamer.getTargetStreamer(); FooTargetStreamer &amp;ATS = static&#95;cast&lt;FooTargetStreamer &amp;&gt;(TS);

The base classes FooTargetAsmStreamer and FooTargetELFStreamer should <em>never</em> be treated differently. Callers should always talk to a FooTargetStreamer.

Definition at line 94 of file <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/mc/mcstreamer-h">MCStreamer.h</a>.

### emitRawBytes() {#ac4b91d37e671f74e4a67bef3ed4577f7}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>void MCTargetStreamer::emitRawBytes (<a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/stringref">StringRef</a> Data)</>}
  labels = {["virtual"]}>
Emit the bytes in <code>Data</code> into the output.

This is used to emit bytes in <code>Data</code> as sequence of .byte directives.
